editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE HAUNTED TOWER, A COMIC OPERA IN THREE ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, DRURY-LANE.
DUBLIN: Printed for P. BURNE, Grafton-Street; and J. JONES, College Green.

div.stage: SCENE I.—The Sea, Dover Clifts and Caſtle—Thunder and Light'ning.
Lewis and ſeveral Attendants of Lady Elinor appear in a boat, they land—then Enter Fiſhermen and Peaſants, male and female different ſides, who ſing the following

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: TO Albion's Genius raiſe the ſtrain,
Whoſe power has aw'd the angry main,
And gives us ſhelter on the coaſt
Of this bleſt iſle; old Ocean's boaſt.
See, retiring o'er the deep
Diſtant lightnings harmleſs ſweep;
The ſtorm condemn'd to loſe its prey,
In hollow murmurs dies away.

div.stage: Fiſhermen and Peaſants Exit on each ſide, Lady Elinor and Cicely appear in a boat and land. Lady Elinor plainly dreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Cicely
sp.p: Now madam, give me leave to congratulate you on your ſafe arrival on the Engliſh coaſt.

sp.speaker: Lady Elinor
sp.p: Ah Cicely, if the ſtorm that oppoſed our landing had fulfilled its threats, it wou'd have reliev'd me from a world of miſery.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p:
Are you then reſolv'd to obey your father and become the victim of his ambition, by marrying
the young Baron of Oakland, whom you have never ſeen?

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: I am, at leaſt I think I am.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: O, Madam! how can you determine to forget Sir Palamede, he who loves you ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Poor Palamede, yet, why was he abſent when I left my father's court? why did he not bid me adieu?—

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Madam, moſt of your attendants are come aſhore, but it's a great way to Oakland Caſtle, and its very cold.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Why, Madam, at this good old lady's cottage, where there is a charming fire, and I wou'd adviſe you madam, to go there and warm yourſelf, for I am ſure you muſt be very cold.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: [To Lewis who offers to follow.] Where are you going ſot? Stay here and wait for the reſt of Lady Elinor's attendants; and do you hear, the next voyage you take, I wou'd adviſe you to keep yourſelf ſober.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Why, that's very pretty indeed, ſo, I am to ſtay here freezing by way of a direction poſt, I got tipſey and loſt my money in France, and began to come to myſelf, when I was about half ſeas over; and now when I thought, I ſhou'd be comfortable by a good fire, I muſt remain freezing here, in all the horrors of ſobriety. It is the fate of genius to make diſcoveries by which other people profit—why, who have we here? ſure it can't be! yes it is—what my dear Maſter, Sir Palamede!

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Is that Lewis?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Yes ſir, I was Lewis, till I was froze into an iſicle, how did you come over from Normandy?

sp.speaker: L, Wil
sp.p: In the ſame ſhip with you, though concealed from the knowledge of Lady Elinor.

sp.speaker: Lew
L. Wil
sp.p: I ſaw your Lady land, whither is ſhe gone?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Why, Sir, to a cottage hard by, where is ſuch a delighful fire-ſide:—Oh, I wiſh, I dar'd, follow her.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Go, thither inſtantly—and ſay, I intreat permiſſion to fulfil my duty in attending her.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: I'll be there immediately, but may I ſay I came by your orders.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Yes, begone!— [Exit Lewis.] To what a wayward fate, am I ſubjected to love!—without hope and to purſue diſappointment.

lg.l: From Hope's fond dream tho' Reaſon wake,
In vain ſhe points with warning hand;
I dread advice I cannot take,
Love's powerful ſpells my ſteps command,
The bird, thus faſcination binds,
When darting from the ſerpent's eyes,
The fatal charm too late he finds,
He ſtruggles, and admiring dies.

div.stage: Enter Lady Elinor, Cicely and Lewis.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: How Lewis, Sir Palamede in the ſame ſhip with us, and coming here immediately!

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Yes Madam, if he is not froze by the way.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p:
[Aſide to Cicely] Oh, Cicely! aſſiſt me to conceal my joy.—What can Sir Palamede
mean by ſurprizing me thus?—agreeably—oh! heavens he is here.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Pardon my intruſion Madam! an humble dependant on the Lord de Courcy, may well dread his preſumption.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Sir, the clandeſtine manner, in which you quitted my father's court, renders it impoſſible for me to conſider you as his friend.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Oh, forgive me!—long I ador'd you in ſecret, and ſhou'd have fallen a ſilent ſacrifice to my preſumptuous love.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Was it well done to take advantage of my father's friendſhip for you, and watch an opportunity to triumph over the weakneſs of his daughter—not that you ever will triumph over her weakneſs;—but—but why did you follow me?

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Ah Sir, why did you follow my Lady?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Deſtiny compelled me hither, compelled me to a land where my footſteps are forbidden, where my preſence is a treaſon, where my life is proſcrib'd!

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Good heaven, what have you to fear!

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Nothing: for I have loſt you.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: I muſt not truſt myſelf to pity him—Yet how can I avoid it, in ſeeing him unhappy.

lg.head: AIR— Lady Elinor.
lg.l: Tho' pity I can not deny,
Ah! what will that avail you?
Alas! I dare not hope ſupply,
For hope too ſure wou'd fail you.
Think when the flatterer ſhall deceive,
In vain you will repent you;
Yet ſhould you hope without my leave,
•… is true I can't prevent you,
My hand directed to beſtow,
In England here I'm landed;
And daughters always act, you know,
Juſt as they are commanded.
Then let not flattering hope deceive,
Or elſe you will repent you;
Yet ſhou'd you hope without my leave,
'Tis true I can't prevent you.

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Sir; I beg your honour's pardon for my boldneſs, but do you accompany the Lady, becauſe my Grandſon, Martin here, will be your guide to the Baron of Oakland's Caſtle.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Why, do you know the Baron of Oakland?

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Aye Sir: I knew him before he was a great man!

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Yes Sir, ſo did I, for all he holds his head ſo high now, and quite forgets when he was plain Edmund, the Ploughman.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: What, d'ye ſay—why then who is this lord?

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Ah, Sir, it does not become poor folks to ſpeak ill of people behind their backs, for that it might get to their ears again.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: No Sir; as my grandmother ſays, it don't become poor folks to ſay.—

sp.speaker: L, Wil
sp.p: Pſha, it becomes every one to ſpeak the truth—torment my curioſity no longer.

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Why, then Sir, you muſt know that about ten years ago, the old Baron, Lord William, was accuſed of being in a plot, and conſpiring againſt the life of our good King William, the Conqueror, and was baniſhed.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: He took with him his only ſon, a fine youth, about twelve years of age; but, alas! Sir, he has not been heard of ſince.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: I am all impatience?

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Now Sir, about a year ago, Lord William's wicked accuſer died, and declared the good baron innocent.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: The King willing to make reperation, for the wrongs he had done him, endeavoured to find him, but all in vain, therefore his lands and eſtates have been in poſſeſſion of a diſtant relation of the family;—then ſir, there is a young baron the preſent heir to.—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Aye and a pretty fellow he is too,—you may go in good woman, we have no further occaſion for you I believe.

sp.speaker: Maud
sp.p: Good woman—Marry, come up I ſay, have I lived all theſe years to be call'd good woman, by a lady's waiting maid! come along Martin—a good woman indeed!

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Good woman indeed!

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: I have heard the whole ſtory Palemede.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Oh, Cicely!—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Oh Cicely!—ah, you may ſpare your long ſpeeches, poor Palamede!—you are in a ſad delima truly, and have'nt wit enough to extricate yourſelf; but want me to help you, I pity you to be ſure, but I can't help laughing at you.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: I have now ſtill ſtranger motives for wiſhing to accompany Lady Elinor to the Caſtle, motives you cannot gueſs at.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Well, Well! ſo you ſhall, leave the management of the affair to me, and don't you appear till we are ſetting off.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: I want words to thank you.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: I am very glad of it, for words would take up too much of our time at preſent, but away and wait till I ſend for you, [Exit Lord William] well wou'd we were at our journey to Oakland Caſtle, I wiſh to ſee this baron's ſon,—Dear Curioſity how I long to—gratify you!

lg.l: Nature to woman ſtill ſo kind,
Among her beſt boons beſtowing;
What every female ſure muſt find,
A wond'rous deſire to be knowing.
Man, the proud and envious elf,
So jealous of our diſcerning;
Decries in us, what he prides in himſelf,
The wiſh, for whatever's worth learning.

div.stage: Enter Robert, and Huntſmen,—in the courſe of the ſong, ſeveral Huntſmen enter.

lg.head: AIR— Robert and Chorus.
lg.l: Hark! the ſweet horn proclaims afar,
Againſt the ſtag the mimic war;
While future heroes' hearts rebound,
And pant to hear the trumpet ſound.
The warlike genius of our iſle,
Who on the hunter deigns to ſmile,
In echoes gives the chace applauſe,
Which ſtrings the nerve for Glory's cauſe:
Where e'er the devious chace may bend,
Still freedom ſhall our ſteps attend;
And bid us, as her pleaſures riſe,
Defend the bleſſings which we prize.

sp.speaker: Ed
sp.p: [Without] How are ye my lads?—How are ye?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: O, here comes our young Maſter, Lord Edward

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Does your Lordſhip hunt to day?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: [Sees Adela at the cottage window, and makes ſigns to her.] No, Robert not this morning.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: What Sir! do you give up the chace when the game's in view: [Points to Adela's window.]

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Huſh, that's my dear Adela, whom I told you of; ſhe arrived here yeſterday evening unknown to any body—if you betray the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: I, Sir! no, no, I am your father's butler, the poſt of all others which I love, and while I have the management of the wine cellar, it is quite indifferent to me how the world wags;—ſo I ſhall follow the Huntſmen.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: But hark'ye Robert, not a word about the Haunted Tower, or you will frighten her out of her wits.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: No, no, Sir—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Here comes father, ſtrutting along; ecod he did not ſtrut ſo when he followed the plough.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Heyday, how dare you appear abroad without your ſervants with you, why are you walking alone?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Why father, if one muſt always move in a crowd, one might as well be bell-weather, to a flock of ſheep.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Sirrah, Sirrah; don't put me in a paſſion, you have been civil to thoſe raſcals, I know you have, why don't you frown at 'em as I do? how often have I told you, there's nothing ſupports dignity like ill-humour: but you have no ambition.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Not much indeed.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, have'nt you more pride? hey, if you are not proud you dog, I'll break your bones.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Why, I can't help nature, father.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Nature; why, look at me, do you ſee any thing like nature about me? No, no, yet I, myſelf, am as vulgarly and naturally pleaſed as any body; but I'll not ſhow it, I'll defy the beſt friend I have to ſay, I have given him a civil word ſince I have been Baron of Oakland—an't I the terror of the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Yes, that you are; eſpecially ſince you impriſoned the poor fellow for catching a hare—and it is proved ſince that he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Innocent, I am very ſorry for it—that is—I ſhou'd be ſorry, if I was not a Baron—give him this money; [Gives Edward money] but don't let him know it comes from me, but tell him I have the power to hang him; for I will have no man dare to think I am in the wrong; juſtice holds her ſeat in my breaſt, and is to all parties equal and indifferent.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Very indifferent indeed.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: What's that you ſay? if I deſired you to behave ill to other people, I did'nt mean you ſhould to me—do you know who I am? that I am the Baron of Oakland, and that all dignity flows me.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Yes, it flows from you pretty faſt, I think none ſeems to ſtay with you.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Don't you grumble Sirrah, but do you hear? prepare to receive the Lord de Courcy's daughter, whom I intend for your wife, I expect her arrival every day.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: But perhaps I may not like her, father.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: That may be, but you ſhall marry her for all that, I inſiſt on it, aye; and love her too—no,—I don't know that I may inſiſt upon that.

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, you impudent ſcoundrels, how dare you laugh ſo! I'll have no perſons to attend upon me that have'nt a proper reſpect for my dignity—follow me you raſcals—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: I hope I ſhall be too ſharp for you, tho' father, for I am determined to marry nobody but Adela, [knocks at the cottage door and retires, after calling, Adela! Adela!]

div.stage: Enter Adela from the cottage looks ſurprized at not ſeeing Edward!

lg.head: AIR— Adela.
lg.l: Whither my love! ah! whither art thou gone!
Let not thy abſence cloud this happy dawn.
Say—by thy heart, can falſehood e'er be known?
Ah! no, no, I judge it by my own.
The heart he gave with ſo much care,
Which treaſur'd in my breaſt I wear;
Still for its maſter beats alone,
I'm ſure the ſelfiſh thing's his own.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Oh, my dear Edward! I am glad you are here, I have got a thouſand queſtions to aſk you—is the Lady Elinor de Courcy arrived yet?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: She is not, ſo all you have to do is, to dreſs yourſelf in the cloaths I gave you, and to paſs upon father for her.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Egad, and ſo I will—I always long'd to be a fine lady, but how ſhall I manage to behave like one?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Faith, I can't tell you—however, it don't ſignify, any thing will paſs upon father.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: But are you ſure now Edward, he has not much dignity, if he has, I ſhall only be confounded and look fooliſh; but is he much like a great gentleman?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! heav'n bleſs you, father is no more like a gentleman than I am—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I am glad of it, for the preſence of our great quality folks always takes my breath away, and tho' I cough and hem, for an hour, the deuce a word can I get out.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p:
'Tis juſt the ſame with me—tho' I am a Baron's ſon, for my part, I never feel myſelf ſo
much like a great man, as when I am with the ſervants—I hate talking to my betters.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I am pleaſed to hear you ſay ſo, I was afraid you would have forgot poor Adela, for the rich lady, de Courcy.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: What marry a woman of quality—oh! I ſhall be a loſt man; I ſhou'd never be able to make free with her—ſhou'd ſhe uſe me ever ſo ill, I cou'd never venture to ſcold her.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: But when you marry me—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Oh! I love you ſo much, that I cou'd ſcold you with the greateſt ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: But won't marriage—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Never fear Adela, love has hitherto been our conſtant attendants—I'll warrant you he'll follow us to church.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ay, but they ſay, he has a ſad knack of leaving married couples at the church door.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Pſha, love and marriage are better friends then you think for.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, perhaps they are beſt friends at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: No, no, like true friends, love and marriage muſt meet together, to perfect the happineſs of both—Oh! Adela, when I come to the title and eſtate, and you are my lady.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Oh, we ſhall be as happy as the day is long.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Aye, and the night into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Then ſuch dancing—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: And ſuch tilting and cudgel playing.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: And ſuch fine talking and ſinging—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: And then ſuch eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: And ſuch fine company, and then.—

lg.l: Will great lords and ladies,
Dreſt up on gay days,
Come to viſit you and I?
All ſmiling, bowing,
Great friendſhip vowing,
While we hold our heads ſo high.
But ſhou'd the fine gentry ſmoke us,
Lud! how they'll joke us;
How they'll laugh at ſilly me.
Pſhaw, we ſhall be ever
Reckon'd vaſtly clever,
While our pocket's full, d'ye ſee.
Then every day
New joy ſhall bring,
And ever gay
We'll dance and ſing.
Fall lall de rall,
How merry ſhall we be.
Of great fortune vaunting,
Low people taunting,
Dignity we muſt ſupport.
'Mong high barons bouncing,
Fine ladies flouncing,
We may chance to go to court,
Well, fegs, I care not,
Court, tho' we ſhare not,
If at home we happy be.
Soon I may be bold
To hope that I ſhall hold
A little baron on my knee.
Then every day
New joy ſhall bring,
And ever gay
We'll dance and ſing.
Fall lall de rall,
How merry ſhall we be.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Here let us remain, till I gain ſome intelligence of the object of our ſearch, I am ſure my ſiſter and her attendants muſt have been on board that very ſhip, which we ſaw at a diſtance in the late ſtorm.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Well Charles! what news of my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: My lord, I learn that the lady de Courcy is on her road to the Baron of Oakland's Caſtle, which is at no great diſtance.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: And Sir Palamede—

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: My lord, I am ſorry to ſay he is with her.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Infamy, and diſhonour! but I will purſue her, and avenge the wrongs of my family; go forward Charles, and procure every intelligence you can gain—I ſhall wait for you within a mile of the Baron's Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: I will, becauſe it is my duty; but wou'd I were in Normandy again, nothing ſhou'd induce me to quit it, except my regard for ſo good a maſter.

lg.l: My native land I bade adieu,
And calmly Friendſhip's joys reſign'd;
But ah! how keen my ſorrows grew,
When my love I left behind.
Yet ſhould her truth feel no decay,
Should abſence prove my charmer kind,
Then ſhall I not lament the day,
When my love I left behind.

div.stage: Enter Lord William, Lady Elinor, and Cicely.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Well! Palamede, I will frankly own to you, that the account, I hear of the Baron of Oakland's ſon, is far from pleaſing me; and though I dare not diſobey my father, yet I will do every thing in my power to delay the marriage—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: In ſhort, Si,r my lady agrees to my ſcheme of viſiting the caſtle as Lady Elinor's Attendant till ſhe h • ars further from the Baron, her father.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Tranſporting tidings!

lg.head: TRIO— Lord William, Cicely and Lady Elinor.
lg.l: Againſt the ſhaft of cruel fate,
Why cannot virtue prove a charm,
And of her blind miſguided hate,
Capricious Deſtiny diſarm?
Yet who engag'd in Virtue's cauſe,
To tread her paths wou'd fear confeſs,
And on the road reluctant pauſe,
Becauſe it leads not to ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Well Robert!

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Make yourſelf perfectly eaſy, friend Hugo, every thing ſhall be in perfect order to receive Lady Elinor.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Aye, I hope ſo, for the honour of the family; It is near three ſcore years ſince I was firſt a ſervant in Oakland Caſtle, and have ſeen three poſſeſſions of it; I have come down from father to ſon, with the reſt of the old furniture.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: And a fine tough piece of Engliſh Oak you are.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: I remember the death of Edmund Ironſide and the reſtoration of Canute; I remember the Harolds and Hardy Canute, and the good King Edward the Confeſſor; and I remember the good Baron, who now haunts the old Tower.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Huſh! no more of that.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Ah Robert, if you were old enough to remember what I can.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: I am juſt as well pleaſed as it is.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: We ſhall have muſick and dancing enough at the wedding, I hope Robert—for the honor of Lord Edward.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Yes, yes, when a man is deſperate to attack matrimony, the more noiſe and buſtle the better; like trumpets in a battle, it drowns reflection and prevents cowardice.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Are all the pikes and javelins burniſhed up, and the armoury put in order, and the large ſtag's horns in the hall duſted?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Horns are moſt ominous wedding decorations—No, no, friend Hugo, I have ordered the horns to be taken down.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul! why, I remember 'em in the family theſe fifty years.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: For which reaſon, the young lady ought not to ſee them.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Then is the Lady Elinor very beauteous Robert?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Why do you aſk Hugo, do you admire beauty yet?

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Oh yes, Robert! I never could yet behold a beauteous woman without admiration; the ſetting ſun may ſurely cheer my ſight tho' it cannot warm my heart.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: I hope Adela has got her fine cloaths on, to paſs for Lady Elinor—O! here ſhe comes!

div.stage: Enter Adela, elegantly dreſs'd from a door in the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well, here I am at laſt ready dreſs'd, to paſs for a fine lady; but how long ſhall I remain ſo?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Why, you are now in the high road to ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Aye: but there is ſo many turnings and windings that one is never ſure of being right,

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: What! Madam with ſuch a guide as Merit.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, Merit is often apt to lead one a ſtray;—Oh dear! I do think the old Baron is coming—hey, O no! he is'nt—O! I wiſh the meeting was over.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: You have no idea, how much you look like a woman of quality!—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Nature certainly intended you for a fine Lady.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Then indeed ſhew as very much miſtaken; for I never in all my life cou'd tell a lie, without bluſhing; ſo I am ſure I ſhall never do for a fine lady.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: But I hope you have your leſſon by heart.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O ay, let me ſee, I am come over from Normandy, from my friends, and arrived here to day, did'nt I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: You did ma'am.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: And anxious to pay my reſpects to the Baron of Oakland, left my ſervants on the road?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O! but there's one material circumſtance I have forgot, I don't know who my father is.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: That may happen in the beſt regulated families; however, I'll tell you—your father is the Baron de Courcy of Normandy, a great favorite of our good King William, and you will remember, that the King wrote to your father, recommending this marriage.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well, I'll endeavour to recollect if I can, but you know it is not very ſtrange, I ſhou'd forget what never happened.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Well madam! I will go and acquaint my lady of your arrival—and pray be careful in what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p:
You may depend on it Sir, I'll not ſpeak truth if I can poſſibly help it. [Exit Robert.] Theſe gay trappings hang very much in my way, I ſhall make a ſad fine lady I fear; I wiſh I cou'd
fancy myſelf in my every day cloaths again, when I think where I am and on what occaſion, I wonder at my own confidence! Nothing but love cou'd have inſpired it, and to gain my dear Edward, I wou'd attempt a thouſand times as much!

lg.head: AIR— Adela.
lg.l: Be mine, tender paſſion, ſoother of care,
Life's choiceſt bleſſing, ſhield from deſpair;
Do not deceive me, ah! never leave me,
Still may my boſom thy power declare.
In vain thy influence fools may revile,
Conſtancy ever gains thy ſmile.
And of their deſtiny can thoſe complain;
Whoſe falſehood dares thy laws profane?
Reſolv'd I brave all danger, to every fear a ſtranger;
Thy ſweet rewards, oh, Love to gain.
Then let me combat not in vain;
But in my triumph ſhare,
Thy ſmiles, for which I bravely dare.

sp.p: O! here he comes, ah! its all over—I ſhall never be able to get thro':

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Ah! there ſhe is ſure enough—ſhe ſeems very pretty, what a fine eye ſhe has. [Aſide to Robert.]

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: My courage fails me—'twill never do I find!— Aſide,]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Her coming ſo ſuddenly is ſo curſed unlucky, I don't know what to ſay to her, I have not got my ſpeech in my pocket; ſhe turns her back upon me. I believe ſhe is very proud— [Aſide to Robert.]

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ay, now he is laughing at my aukwardneſs—I wiſh he • d ſpeak firſt, [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Well, come if I muſt ſpeak, here goes—My lady, the joy!—I ſay my lady the joy!—that is joy my lady creates happineſs—and is—is—joy my lady—which joy I ſay my lady is—I hope your Ladyſhip is pretty well.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, pure well, I humbly thank your lordſhip—O lord! I am glad it's over, the firſt word is a great matter, [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: She's wonderous, condeſcending, Robert, conſidering her high blood, [Aſide to Robert,]—Well my lady, as you have been in ſuch a hurry as to leave your ſervants on the road, and only to come here on a hop, as a body may ſay; I hope your ladyſhip will have the goodneſs, to excuſe all faults.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O yes, my lord, I'll excuſe all your faults with a good deal of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: All my faults, aye, ſhe has found me out already, [Aſide.]—Why to be ſure my lady, we all have faults; but if one is of a good family, you know my lady, it does'nt ſo much ſignify.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O! to be ſure not, for though ſome people are a little aukward and baſhful before company, yet I don't think they are a bit the worſe for that.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: No, no—that's a hit at me— [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: For you know my lord, if one is not uſed to ſtrange company, one's very apt to look like a fool—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p:
Ye—e—s ſo one is my lady—yes ſhe means me,
[Aſide,] but come my lady, let's talk of ſomething elſe; how does the lord, your father, I reſpect a man of his great family.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ay my lord, a great family indeed?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Oh, ſhe's proud enough of her high blood, tho', [Aſide] well my lady! no offence, but I fancy I may venture to ſay, my family is equal to his!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Why, I thought Edward told me, he was his only child, [Aſide] indeed my lord!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Aye, indeed my lady;—now my blood is up, I can talk to her, [Aſide] and give me leave to aſſure your ladyſhip, whatever notions you have form'd of a great family, you'll not be diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! [mimicks her aſide,] What the devil does ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I declare your lordſhip makes me laugh, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Yes I ſee I do, but I think your ladyſhip need not be ſo polite as to tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Nay, now your lordſhip looks angry.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Have'nt I reaſon! what did your ladyſhip mean by affronting me, in telling me of your fathers great family!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Why ſo he has, there are eleven of us, boys and girls.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Surprized] Hey, what?

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: [Aſide] O what have I ſaid!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Aſide] O! I ſuppoſe this is ſome quality joke, and that's the reaſon I don't underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Come here ſirrah, there's the Lady Elinor de Courcy! go and talk to her, bid her welcome; and do you hear, don't be baſhful, and diſhonour your family; but attack her with your whole ſtock of impudence.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p:
• baſhful! no I thank you, we people of faſhion know what's what. [Dancing up to Adela.] Tol. de roll.
•… am prodigiouſly happy to ſee your ladyſhip;—hope you left all friends in Normandy well, all right and tight, had good weather, and a good ſhip, no ſea ſickneſs; even we people of faſhion are ſubject to it ſometimes, as well, as well as other people—an't we father—hey!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, the boy's aſſurance aſtoniſhes me—oh! he has touch'd her hand and caught it of her.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: [Aſide to Adela,] Never mind I'll bring you off with the old fellow—ha! ha! ha! a monſtrous good joke indeed, very well faith, very well, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Looks ſurprized and then laughs heartily.] Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: My dear father: Lady Elinor tells me ſhe has joked a little with you, as we people o faſhion do without meaning any thing—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Aye we people of faſhion do, ha! ha! ha! I beg your ladyſhip woud'nt think of it.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Zounds, father don't be baſhful— [To Adela.] why don't you bounce a little as I do.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Well my lady, I am now going to my great hall, where I'll receive you in form, and I believe I ſhall trouble your ladyſhip with a bit of a ſpeech on the occaſion, come my lady—no, no, you muſt not go before me—I am a baron you know, conſider my dignity!

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: I ſay Robert, I think we ſhall be too cunning for old dignity, though:

div.stage: Enter Lord William and Lady Elinor.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: We are at length arrived at Oakland Caſtle, continue your diſguiſe madam, but a little longer.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: And do you Palamede, recommend diſguiſe, you who pretend to be a lover?

lg.l: Huſh, huſh; ſuch counſels do not give,
A lover's name profaning;
And can her heart deceit adviſe,
Where mighty love is reigning?
Diſſimulation's path you've trod
Too oft to go aſtray,
And whilſt to me, you point the road,
Your footſteps mark the way.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Oh! madam here comes the old Baron, but pray think of ſomething melancholy, or you will certainly laugh; nature and art have made him ſuch a ſtrange animal, that he ſeems only to be laugh'd at; but here he is!

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: And is this the repreſentation of our family, degrading thought! but I muſt diſſemble [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [To Cicely] So you are an attendant on lady Elinor de Courcy, hey! but who's that [pointing to Lady Elinor.]

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Oh! that's my lady's own waiting woman, and a very great favourite of my lady's Sir,—I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: She muſt be a great favorite of every body's for ſhe's a monſtrous pretty girl; and pray who is that gentleman, is he a favorite of your ladyſhip's? [pointing to Lord William.]

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: O no! that is—that is Sir Palamede the Baron's Jeſter.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: A curious character ſhe has aſſigned me, but I muſt carry it on, [Aſide]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p:
Why, jeſting is a very pleaſant employment to be ſure, though not a very profitable one.—I
ſhou'd think—hark'ye friend, don't you ſometimes get a bone crack'd?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: You are miſtaken, my lord, we jeſters are privileged people; we anatomize vice and folly.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Ay, that is you cut up people by way of amuſement.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Improvement my lord—ſatire well applied, is the medicine of the mind—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: That may be, but I don't take phyſic, ſo you may ſpare your trouble; and ſo the baron pays you for jeſting, hey? that's one way of enjoying a jeſt, at his own expence; but I ſhou • d think now, ſo good-natured as the world is, that he might contrive to get laugh'd at, Gratis.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Your lordſhip finds it ſo, I have no doubt, now as a ſpecimen.

lg.l: Tho' time has from your lordſhip's face
Made free to ſteal each youthful grace,
Yet why ſhould you deſpair?
Old buſts oft pleaſe the connoiſſeurs,
So folks of taſte, perhaps like yours,
And that removes your care.
'Tis true that ſilly girls believe
In joys that youth alone can give,
But why ſhou'd you deſpair?
'Tis folly governs youth, you know,
And ſo far young you ſoon may grow,
So that removes your care.
Whate'er your faults, in perſon, mind,
(However groſs) you chance to find,
Yet why ſhould you deſpair?
Of flattery you muſt buy advice,
You're rich enough to pay the price,
So that removes your care.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Ah! that's another hit at me, but, I dare not reſent it, [Aſide] well, but if you are attendants on the lady Elinor de Courcy, where have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Oh! Sir, we have left my lady behind on the road.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Your lady has left you behind you mean—why ſhe's here in the caſtle.—

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Yes, indeed, Mr. Jeſt-hunter, and, I am going to give her ladyſhip audience in my Great Hall—and if we want any body to laugh at—we'll ſend for you—there, I hit him I think.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: What can he mean—give me your advice, Palamede.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Ah, madam! you forgot that Sir Palamede is a lover, and conſequently advice is a commodity he does'nt deal in; but if you will take my opinion, ma'am?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: It is plain ſome impoſter has aſſumed your ladyſhip's name, for what purpoſe we muſt endeavour to find out; therefore ſuppoſe we continue our diſguiſe, wait on the mock lady Elinor, overturn her with reſpect and confound her with courteſy—

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Admirable!—

div.stage: Enter Lewis with letters, which he delivers to Lord William.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Sir, the meſſenger is return'd and brought theſe letters—Aye, madam, your ſhadow is here before you, find—

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p:
Huſh! not a word, I charge you; from whom are thoſe letters?
[Aſide to Lewis.]

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: That's what I want to know, I wiſh you wou'd aſk Sir Palamede, the queſtion?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Lady Elinor, every moment furniſhes additiona • reaſons for requeſting you will be guided by Cicely's advice.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Ah! Cicely, there they go, a pair of as true turtles as ever bill'd—Oh! what a fine thing mutual love is if you wou'd but let us follow their example, and fall in love with me in a ſtrange place, now!—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Oh! you may ſpare your rhetoric—I promiſe you. I prize my liberty too much to be talk'd out of it.

lg.l: What bleſt hours, untainted by ſorrow,
Does the maiden prove,
Who knows not love,
So merri'y ſhe ſings thro' the day;
"Dull ſorrow ſhall threaten in vain,
"The delight of heart to reſtrain,
While from Cupid free,
Bleſt in Liberty,
"Not a ſigh ſhe blends with the ſtrain."
As ſhe gaily carols along,
Let me join ſweet Freedom's ſong,
O! may my heart
Ever bear a part,
In the envied jocund lay,
While merry the happy maid,
So blithely ſings thro' the day.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Where the duece is Adela? if we can but get married before ſhe is diſcovered—but, why is ſhe abſent? ſhe for whoſe ſake Oakland Caſtle reſounds with jollity, till the old walls crack to their foundations.

lg.head: AIR— Edward.
lg.l: Now all in preparation,
For the nuptial celebration,
Each maiden on th' occaſion,
Feels her heart in palpitation;
Now a bluſh, and now a ſigh,
Trembling too, ſhe knows not why,
While every lad with expectation,
Finds his heart beats high.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Ah! it's all over, there's an end of our ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I knew how it wou'd happen.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Did you, I wiſh then you had told me ſo before!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well, it's all a ſcheme of your own.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Mine! why you know it was your ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Why did'nt you firſt propoſe it?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Yes, becauſe I was ſure you firſt thought of it.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Why, did I ever leave my ſpinning wheel for fine cloaths? why did I quit my father's cottage.!

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Becauſe I got you a better ſituation to be ſure—you won't deny that I ſent you to a relation's houſe in Suffex, ſix months ago, where you liv'd like a lady, and had nothing to learn, to read all the day along.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: So much the worſe, improving the mind as they call it, only ſerves to make one lazy; in my father's cottage, induſtry took up all our time, Wealth never came near our door.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: If he had, you wou'd have been glad to have aſk'd him in.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: No Sir! there Innocence, and Happineſs were our gueſts.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: 'Twas lucky they did'nt take up much room, or the houſe woud'nt have been big enough to hold 'em—I fancy all the ſpare corners were occupied by birds and beaſts.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well, I own it! we did all ſleep under one roof; the family, the pigs, and poultry all in harmony, peace and friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Except now and then, when you ate ſome of your company for dinner.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: [Sobbing] Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Why look'ee there, now that's always your way, if one ſays any thing to you—you fall a crying!—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: You want to break my heart!—I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: No, I dont—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, you do—

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Why, what ſignifies quarrelling now my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Why, I don't know Robert, ſhe will quarrel I think.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: No, it is you—

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Come be friends I ſay, we are all in a pretty hoble to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, and I believe you brought us into it.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: 'Tis my opinion he did—

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Me!

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, I am ſure, Edward woud'nt have thought of ſuch a thing, if you had'nt put it into his head.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: No, that I ſhoud'nt—

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: You are both very entertaining and ſo I ſhall leave you to yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Nay, but Robert, don't deſert us.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Faith I ſhall make my peace with your father, by falling on my knees, and aſking pardon immediately.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Had'nt we better do the ſame, Edward? for conſider we are all in the ſame boat, and if we pull different ways, we ſhall certainly go to the bottom.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: That is very true,—ſo Robert you ſhall be our pilot.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Well! then we muſt 'een meet the old baron in the hall of audience, at any rate; [how wonderfully does common intereſt beget friendſhip!]

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Adela—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: You forget we have been quarrelling, kiſs and friends, you know— [kiſs and exeunt.]

lg.head: AIR— Edward.
lg.l: While ſwords and ſhields are claſhing,
Archers aiming, cudgels thraſhing,
The ale to none denying,
Flaggons far and wide ſupplying,
With tilters fencing, wreſtlers boaſting.
Bonfires blazing, oxen roaſting;
And all the vaſſals flock around,
What pleaſures now abound!
Now all in preparation,
For the nuptial celebration.

div.stage: SCENE—An Antique Hall, a State Chair on ſeveral People diſcover'd, Tenants, Servants, &c.
Enter Lord William, Lady Elinor, Cicely, Lewis, Martin and Charles.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Well Charles, how did you come over from Normandy?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: Why, Cupid lent me his wings and I hovered over your ſhip—come, come, Cicely you know as well as I, there were more lovers aboard than the Captain knew of—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: I believe I had better aſk no more queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Lewis, come hither, you are ſure that not a whiſper has eſcaped you; likely to diſcover Lady Elinor.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Lord, Sir! I have done nothing but ate and drink ſince I have been here, ſo that I have no time for talking.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: And our honeſt guide here: [pointin got Martin.]

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir, he has been ſo taken up between hunger and wonder—that he has not thought of ſecrets.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: You are certain the ſervants know what to do Cicely?

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: O yes, madam, I have given them all their leſſons, and you'll ſee them receive the mock Lady Elinor, as you cou'd wiſh, but ſee, ſhe comes!—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Now, ma'am, to compleat their aſtoniſhment!

lg.stage: Lord William, Cicely, and Lady Elinor.
lg.l: By mutual love delighted,
Here Fortune's fav'rites ſee,
In Hymen's bonds united,
How happy muſt they be.
Whom can they mean?—not me.
Nor me.
Ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for me.
What grace!—what an air!
A face ſo fair.
Born to command the happy pair.

lg.stage: Lord William, Cicely, and Lady Elinor.
lg.l: By mutual love delighted,
Here Fortune's fav'rites ſee, &c.
In Hymen's bonds united,
How happy muſt they be.
Egad the joke we'll humour;
With all my heart, ſay I.
Who for ſucceſs can do more,
Than every chance to try,
Her courage faulters—mark her eyes;
See from her cheek the colour flies.
Poor girl—I pity her diſtreſs,
Yet Miſchief ſays we can't do leſs.
You tremble—courage—come, go on,
Ah me! my boaſted ſpirit's gone;
Alas! why didſt thou, hapleſs maid,
By ſilly vanity betray'd,
Expoſe thy peace of mind to gain
A prize, thou never canſt obtain?

div.stage: Enter Baron,—Struts to the Chair, ſits down with great ceremony, then riſes, and ſpeaks; his hat in his hand with the ſpeech in it—which he occaſionally looks at.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Hem! my Lady Elinor de Courcy—now ſome men in my ſituation, wou'd make you a ſet ſpeech on the occaſion; but I ſhall give your ladyſhip a touch off hand; as to your great family, my lady, all the world knows that—and as to your beauty—why that ſpeaks for itſelf, as a body may ſay;—but I ſay, when I conſider, my lady—I ſay—when I conſider how vain it wou'd be to number your numberleſs qualifications, and when I think of your goodneſs, in—confering this viſit—I want words— [Edward takes the ſpeech ſlily out of his father's hat:] I ſay, my Lady Elinor, I want words to— [miſſes the ſpeech.] Hey! egad, I do want words!—I ſay—madam—my ladyſhip I,—I,—I, want words!—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: If my father had not wanted words madam, he would have attempted to expreſs, his inexpreſſible ſatisfaction—but 'tis juſt as well as it is—the leſs that's ſaid, the more there is to gueſs at.

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.p: My Lord! a gentleman wiſhes to ſpeak with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: I come to him. [Exit ſervant.] I declare my lady! I am quite aſham'd that I—.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O, pray my lord make no apologies!—you know you want words, and it is quite time to have done, when one has'nt any more to ſay—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Aye, my lady, but I had a great deal more to ſay—if I had'nt loſt my ſpeech— [aſide and exit.]

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: [To Edward] I can't make out the meaning of all this, I don't underſtand the jeſt!—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Nor I, upon my ſoul—but I'll try to find it out, for my part I think we are in a dream.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I am ſure it is a very pleaſant one, I have'nt the leaſt deſire to be wak'd from it.

div.stage: [They Sing part of the laſt Air again, and exeunt, Lord William, Lady Elinor, Cicely, Lewis, Charles, Edward, Adel., and Robert.]

lg.stage: Lord William, Cicely, Lady Elinor, Charles, and Robert.
lg.l: Alas! behold the ſilly maid,
By pride by vanity betray'd:
Expoſe her peace of mind to gain
A prize ſhe never can obtain.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: This way my lord, this way, I am glad to ſee your lordſhip—

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Huſh, my lord! remember that I am here in diſguiſe; I muſt depend on your friendſhip, to conceal me from my ſiſter's attendants, till I am revenged on Sir Palamede—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: And ſo this Palamede—

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: He has long privately lov'd my ſiſter, but the mean advantage he has now taken of our confidence in him—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O! hang him, an abuſive ſneering knave, to paſs on me for your lordſhip's jeſter; I wiſh I had known this—

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: But we muſt be cautious— [Laughing within.] dark! what noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Only my vaſſals carouſing, in conſequence of this marriage of your ſiſter's in our family.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: The ſounds of feſtivity, but ill accord with my feelings; a more retired apartment might ſuit our purpoſe better.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Certainly, my lord, private concerns, muſt give way to public juſtice.

div.stage: SCENE—The Kitchen, Tenants and Servants, diſcovered at different tables—at the upper end an Ox, roaſting, Cooks, &c. baſting it.

lg.l: Now mighty roaſt beef is the Engliſhman's food,

It ennobies our veins, and
〈◊〉 our blood,

Our ſoldiers are brave, and our
•… ons are good.
Oh! the roaſt beef of Old England, and Old Engliſh roaſt beef.
Our barons, my boys, are robuſt, ſtout and ſtrong,
And keep open houſe with good cheer all day long,
Which makes their plump tenants rejoice in this ſong,
Oh! the roaſt beef, &c.

div.stage: Enter Lord William, Lady Elinor, and Cicely.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Come, my lads and laſſes, at this feaſt every one muſt contribute to the common ſtock of merriment, that is the only reckoning we have to pay.

lg.l: Love's ſweet voice to Hymen ſpeaking
Breathing thro' the dulcet flute;
Liſt • ning joy the accents ſeeking,
Bids complaining Care be mute.
High above dull Sorrow's level,
Now the tide of joy diſplay;
Love and Hymen bid us revel,
Bid us hail this happy day.
Let the vine's enlivening treaſure
Riſing kiſs the goblet's brim,
Till we ſee exulting pleaſure,
On the ſmiling ſurface ſwim.
High above dull Sorrow's level,
Now the generous tide diſplay;
'Tis gay Bacchus bid us revel,
Bids us hail this happy day.
While the merry bells reſounding,
Shall in pleaſure's chorus chime,
From the trembling floor rebounding,
Let the varied dance beat time.
High above dull Sorrow's level,
Now the tide of joy diſplay,
Love and Hymen bid us revel,
Bid us hail this happy day.

sp.speaker: De Courcy,
sp.p: YOU are ſure that the ſoldiers are plac'd at every avenue to the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Char
sp.p: My lord, it is impoſſible Sir Palamede ſhou'd eſcape!

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: And you ſay, you obſerv'd him this evening?

sp.speaker: Char
sp.p: I did, my lord, and notwiſtanding he appear'd to join the general feſtivity; yet at times he ſigh'd ſo piteouſly, that I cou'd not help ſaying to myſelf, your honour cou'd never find in your heart to kill ſo brave a gentleman.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Leave me and be ready at the time appointed—and ſhall this ſlave boaſt a virtue to which I am a ſtranger—ſhall his rugged heart feel compaſſion for wretched, whilſt I unmoved doom to deſtruction, him! who has been my Companion!—my Friend!—my Brother!— [Aſide,] Poor Palamede, I will ſee him and converſe with him—perhaps he is not ſo guilty as he appears—at leaſt let me remember that he is unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Char
sp.p: There ſpoke the generous feelings of de Courcy.

lg.head: AIR— Charles.
lg.l: Where'er true valour can its power diſplay,
There meek-ey'd Pity, anxious ſtill to bleſs,
With jealous honour holds divided ſway,
And from avenging anger ſhields diſtreſs.
Ne'er ſhall the ſword of Honour dare invade
The ſpell bound ſpot, where Pity drops a tear;
For where Misfortune caſts her ſacred ſhade,
There deepeſt injury muſt diſappear,

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O, my lord de Courcy, I am glad I have found you, I have ſtrange news to tell you: only think my lord, when I thought my vaſſals had retired fatigued, and gone dutifully drunk to bed, the whole village is up and ſcouring their old helmets and armour; I am ſure there's miſchief in the wind when theſe raſcals are ſo induſtrious.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf my lord, you ſeem quite alarm'd!—

sp.speaker: Bar
De Cour
sp.p: Perhaps then he has heard of my arrival, and finding himſelf diſcovered, means to oppoſe force by force.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: You are right my lord, he has been ſending and receiving letters and meſſages all night in a continual ebb and flow of miſchief.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: S'death, can he deſcend ſo low as to miſlead the rabble into revolt—the traitor ſhall periſh—but where is my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: I don't know my lord, but here comes my ſon, I dare ſay he'll tell you.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Do not diſcover me yet, even to him.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why my lord, as he is ſhortly to be related to your lordſhip, I can't ſee that it ſignifies—but it ſhall be as you pleaſe; harkee ſirrah! come here, where is lady Elinor?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: In her own room, I took her a cup of wine juſt now—but the dear creature prefer'd ale: ſhe ſeems prodigiouſly fond of ale.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Who! Lady Elinor, Sir?

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Yes Sir, Lady Elinor, my wife that is to be; what have you to ſay to that? Sir!

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Pardon me Sir,—but are you aſſured of the lady's affections?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Aye ſirrah, are you ſure that ſhe is fond of you.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Fond of me, ha! ha! ha! dammee look at me!

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: I believe ſhe was once attached to another, one Sir Palamede.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: I believe not friend, and my reaſon for thinking ſo, is that the dear little wench never ſaw Sir Palamede in all her life.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Sir, when you name that lady, you ſhou'd remember the reſpect due to her family.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: [Snaps his finger] That for her family—ſhe is a bud of beauty, which I have gather'd to wear next my heart, and the devil may take the reſt of the family-tree for me, here ſhe comes i'faith—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Ah! my dear lady Elinor—

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment!—this muſt be ſome plot of Palamede's, [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, my lord, your ſiſter does not ſeem to know you.—ah, this is another quality joke, now I'll be ſworn.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: He is deceived too! [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, my lord, I think there's a very ſtrong family likeneſs between you.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: I perceive my lord, you are impoſed on, but you ſhall ſoon be avenged.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p:
How impoſed on! O, he means they have been joking on me,—ay but he was ſerious;—egad, I believe I ſhou'd be angry,—but then if
I ſhou'd be in the wrong;—I'll e'en go after him and aſk whether I ought to be in a paſſion or not.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Why, I ſay Edward, the Lady Elinor's attendants did call me their lady for the jok's ſake; yet it muſt ſoon be out that I am myſelf.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: That's not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: And if Lady Elinor ſhou'd be as handſome, as we heard, and your father ſhou'd be very preſſing—

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Then you think I ſhou'd deſert you!—hah.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Your deſerting me wou'd then be called by another name, for fine folks have fine names for bad actions, to make them ſeem like good ones.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Why, look'ye. my dear Adela,—I was always a blundering fellow at a fine ſpeech; [ecod I am like my father for that,] but if I thought my being a nobleman wou'd make me love you a jot the leſs, deuce take me if I had not rather remain a ploughman all my life,—now do you believe me?

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: I do.

lg.l: Love from the heart, all its danger concealing,
Reaſon they ſay, the fond ſpell can remove;
But bliſs kindly ſtealing,
Still the deluſion ſo ſweet may I prove.
For ſhould you betray me, your falſehood perceiving,
Too well do I love you, the peril to ſhun:
So if you muſt cheat me, ſtill further deceiving;
Oh! blinded by hope, to the laſt leads me on.

div.stage: SCENE—The Sea at the back of the ſtage and a light houſe,—a part of the Tower is ſeen, the cellar door by the ſecond wing;—a little further, a flight of ſtairs leading to a door,—ſtage lights down.

sp.p: Why, did I not inſiſt on Sir Palamed eexplaining this myſtery?— [She retires up the ſtage.]

Welcome, thrice welcome, ye ſcenes which remind me of happier days;—every ſtep I take—every object of remembrance, warms me with new incitements to aſſert my birthright,— [Lady Elinor comes forward,] How Lady Elinor!

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: O Palamede! for heaven's ſake, why this myſtery?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Spare me the explanation of what is yet improper for you to know;—ſhew me eſteem by confiding in my honour,—he who is beloved by you, cannot act unworthily.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: I am uneaſy only on your account,—therefore do not flatter me, or keep me longer in ſuſpence!

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: To night is the Criſis of my fate, and to-morrow's ſun ſhall diſpel the cloud of myſtery in which it is involved.

lg.head: DUET— Lord William and Lady Elinor.

lg.l: Dangers unknown impending,
Doubt multiplies my fears,
Laurels my ſteps attending,
Shall ſpring from beauty's tears.
Thus in ſuſpence to leave thee,
Think'ſt thou, I can deceive thee?
—To leave thee.
—To leave thee!
Say, wilt thou ſtill prove true?
Yes, I will ſtill prove true.
And muſt we bid adieu?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Cruel concealment, yet it muſt be ſo, one only have I truſted in this caſtle and he is here.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Ah! my dear young maſter, what pleaſure does your old ſervant feel, in ſeeing you once more in your native land! Heaven help us, what ſtrange events have happened, ſince the good baron your father quitted England.—I long to hear your adventures in France.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: It is a long ſtory my friend.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: So much the better,—I like long ſtories,—I often tell long ſtories myſelf,—remembrance forms the old man's banquet, and let the viands be ever ſo ordinary, memory cooks them to his liking.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Hugo this is not time for words, I muſt ſupport my claim to the honors of my anceſtors and this hour,—

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: What my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p:
Hear me! I have written to an old and allied friend of my father's, a powerful nobleman, and near the king's perſon, he has aſſured me of
my ſovereign's favour,—and I expect hourly letters from the king, acknowledging me Baron of Oakland.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Well my lord!

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: In the mean time my zealous friend. has adviſed me to ſurprize the caſtle without delay, to man all reſiſtance to the king's commands.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p:
Surprize the Caſtle! why my lord, I'll fight as long as I can,
[draws his ſword.] but here are only two of us.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Good old man! I ſhall not need your aſſiſtance, a guard of an hundred choſen troops ſent by the good Lord Hubert, enter'd the village in the duſk of the evening;—the news of my return is receiv'd by the vaſſels with tranſport, and they are this momemt arming in my cauſe.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Then, why do we ſtay here, I'll go and get on my armour?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: It is not yet time;—the tolling of the Curfew will give me notice when all is ready: but tell me Hugo, was not my father's armour kept in an apartment in that Tower?

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Yes, my lord in that very apartment over the wine cellar.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: And has the armour ever been removed from thence?

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Never! I'll anſwer for that,—the room has been ſhut up theſe ten years paſt to my knowledge; I have ſtill preſerv • d my key to the door which leads to it thro' the long gallery,

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Give time, [Hugo gives a key,] now let us be gone.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: Excuſe me my lord, I'll follow you to battle; but not into that apartment.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p:
Ah, my lord I tremble at the thoughts of it, no living ſoul has enter'd that room for theſe ten years,—voices have been heard and lights
ſeen,—in ſhort it is haunted, and tho' I lov'd your worthy father when he was alive—I,—I,—I, [light is ſeen at a window in the Tower.]

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: By heav'n's a light appears thro' the caſement at this moment.

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: And ſo there does, my dear maſter don't be raſh.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Hark! I hear a noiſe from the Tower, wait for me here, [draws] and beware your fears do not betray you, [goes up the ſteps and unlocks the door and exit.]

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: My lord,—my dear lord William don't leave me alone!—he's gone!—oh that curſed Haunted Chamber! I can't ſtay near it—I,—I, find the only means of perſerving my courage is to carry it along with me.

Why, ſure that was old Hugo, yes and with his ſword drawn, oh, he's in the plot!—O lord! O lord! there's the ſpirit playing his illumination tricks in the Haunted Chamber;—Oh, how I long to attack this old rogue Hugo, becauſe I am ſure I cou'd beat him;—aye, but then I dare not venture alone, valour with me is of a companiable nature and don't like ſolitude;—My courage is ſomething like the vine, to produce good fruit it muſt be well ſupported;—hey, ſure I hear ſomebody coming out of my wine-cellar!—egad, I'll ſtep aſide, I may make ſome diſcoveries here.

div.stage: Enter Robert and Martin from the Cellar door.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Well my boy, now I have made you free of our cellar.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: [Half drunk] Give me your hand, give me your hand, Maſter Robert, I'll live and die with you, of all inventions that ever were thought of, there's none to my mind like good eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p:
And for that, Martin, I'll match all Kent, I know the privilege of a diligent butler too well
to ſuffer my maſter to taſte wine till I have approv'd of it.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Aſide] Oh! the villian

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: That's right, that's right, give me your hand again; O Maſter Robert! what a happy dog you are to have the command of ſuch a wine cellar.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Ay, Martin, there I ſit, abſolute monarch of all the proſtrate bottles.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Aſide] Mighty well!—but I'll be even with you raſcalls. [Exit into the Cellar,]

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Well, can you find friend Lewis, in the garden?

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.p: No maſter Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: He has certainly loſt his way, let us go in ſearch of him, Martin?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Aye, Maſter Robert, do you go one way and I'll go the other.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: And to prevent accidents I'll lock the cellar door for the preſent, we'll ſoon return and finiſh the evening. [Locks the door and Exit with Servant.]

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: And ſo the mock Lady Elinor is coming, Cicely?—Yet how can I trifle thus? While Palamede's fate is in ſuſpence.

lg.head: AIR— Lady Elinor.
lg.l: Dread parent of deſpair,
Thou tyrant of my mind,
Who ling'ring ſeem'ſt to ſpair,
To point the worſt behind.
At once compleat my woe,
Diſplay thy ills in ſtore,
Ah! quickly ſtrike the blow!
'Tis all that I implore.

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: Ah madam! it muſt be a ſad thing to be of a good family, thank heaven! I who have no noble blood in my veins have the deareſt of all privileges, that of chuſing a huſband for myſelf.

lg.l: From high birth and all its fetters,
My kind ſtars my lot remove;
I ſhall envy not my betters,
Give me but the youth I love.
Love's the riches of the poor,
A prize that wealth can ne'er procure;
My rich miſtreſs fain wou'd be
Juſt as poor as Cicely.
From high birth, &c.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Theſe waiting maids peſter me to death with queſtions, here they are again,—

sp.speaker: Cice
sp.p: [Aſide to Lady Elinor,] Now madam, to throw her off her gaurd, endeavour to provoke her and gratify your curioſity.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Why, I ſhou'd like it, but ſhe looks as if ſhe could beat me;—pray madam wou'd your ladyſhip pleaſe to go to bed?

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: No, my ladyſhip does not pleaſe to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: No, her ladyſhip does not pleaſe to go to bed.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: It is my duty to wait on your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Well. wait in another room then.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Aye, wait in another room.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: Pray my lady forgive me.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: No, I will not forgive you!—I can't hear it [Aſide] begone! I diſcharge you my ſervice.

lg.l: Begone! I diſcharge you! away from my ſight!
In my preſence appear never after this night.
Your ladyſhip's orders with grief I obey;
Yet, e're I depart, a few words may I ſay?
I'll try to keep my paſſion under,
And treat the flirt with ſilent ſcorn.
You're too poor to move my rage.
Prithee now this wrath aſſuage.
How the ſaucy creature ſtares.
Tell me, madam, why theſe airs.
Tho' pride and folly ſhould intrude,
They can't good breeding pain;
Their ſilly jeſts, ſo bold and rude,
Raiſe laughter and diſdain.
Of rank and education,
What wretched imitation;
Contempt must ſure befal you,
You vain—what ſhall I call you?
Tho' at ſcolding ſo alert,
I fancy now ſhe's really hurt.

sp.stage: [Exit Adela, Robert, Lady Elinor and Cicely.

div.stage: SCENE—A Chamber in the Tower, folding Doors in the back Scene, and arch leading to another Apartment thro' which enter Lord William.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: Now to the object of my ſearch, [opens the doors and diſcovers his fathers armour brings forward the ſword and ſhield] kind fortune I thank thee!—ſacred to the defence of a juſt cauſe, the ſhield of the father ſhall protect his ſon, fighting for the rights of an illustrious family.

lg.head: AIR— Lord William.
lg.l: Spirit of my ſainted ſire,
With ſucceſs my ſoul inſpire,
Deeds of glory done by thee
In mem'ry's mirror now I ſee.
Let the great examples raiſe
Valour's pureſt, brighteſt blaze,
Till the proweſs of my arm
The eye of fickle Conqueſt charm,
And ſame ſhall, when the battle's won,
Declare that I am all thy ſon.
Spirit of my ſainted ſire,
With ſucceſs my ſoul inſpire.
The inſpiration now I feel,
The ardent glow of patriot zeal,
Brighter proſpects now ariſe,
The voice of Conqueſt rends the ſkies.

sp.stage: [Exit and ſhuts the folding doors after him.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Well Lewis! ſince we have met with you at laſt, I'll give you a ſpecimen of Engliſh Hoſpitallity, we have plenty of liquor in the cellar underneath, and egad we'll make a night of it.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: That's right maſter Robert, and I love good eating and drinking, ſo I'll drink with you if it is only to ſhew you I like your company.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: But you have'nt told me yet about this Haunted Tower.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Well, I declare I'm glad of it for your ſake, for I am ſure you muſt be dry after telling ſuch a long ſtory.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Come my boys, lend me a hand, [They bring in a table with wine and ale, and three three-legg'd floos. Robert ſits at the head of the table, Martin and Lewis on each ſide.]

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: What have we got here?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Some of the beſt wine in Chriſtendom, my lad; aye, and ſome of the beſt ale too, which to me, is the beſt of all liquors;—the ſcurvy old knave, my maſter, who I dare ſay is a-bed and a ſleep, little thinks the honour we are doing to his cellar.

sp.speaker: Lewis and Martin
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Now for't my boys, here's to ye!

lg.l: As now we're met, a jolly ſet,
A fig for ſack or ſherry;
Our ale we'll drink,
And our cans we'll clink,
And we'll be wondrous merry
Merry, my hearts—merry, my boys,
We'll ſing with a hey down derry,
The baron himſelf knows no ſuch joys,
We are ſo wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Come, drink about, [ſings] "And we'll be wondrous merry."

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: [Behind, imitates Robert.] "And we'll be wondrous merry."

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Hey day! what's that?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: That, oh! that's an echo, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: An echo! I never obſerv'd one here, I—

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: O Maſter Robert! is'nt this the chamber you ſaid was haunted?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Egad then, its haunted by a jolly ſpirit—ſo here's to the ghoſt!— [ſings] "And we'll be wondrous merry."

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: [Behind, in Lewis's voice] "And we'll be wondrous merry," [a noiſe underneath the stage.]

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: What think ye now?

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Why, I think there's a damn'd noiſe in the cellar, [The trap door that Robert had pointed to is thrown open and knocks down the table, which they had placed on it, and the Baron appears coming thro' it.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient, pray don't let me diſturb you, pray go on, my butler here, ſets you a good example; ſo pray make free with my property,—upon my life this is a very pretty Chamber to be haunted; the ghoſt has an excellent choice, but I never knew that your troubled ſpirits were, ſuch conſummers of ale and wine before. [a knocking at door,] pray who is that? is it any friend or your's gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Yes, pleaſe your worſhipful honour, it is only Hubert with the ſupper.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O! Hubert with the ſupper, is it? deſire him to walk in [the Baron opens the door. Enter Hubert with ſome beef and bread.] Come in Hubert, here are none but friends, O never mind me, come put the ſupper on the table. [Hubert puts it on the table] And now gentlemen ſit down and eat heartily.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: I am much oblig'd to your honour, but I am not hungry now.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: If but your honour wou'd but hear me.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O! with a great deal of pleaſure, honeſt Robert, I was but ill ſituated in the cellar to hear that catch you ſung juſt now;—rogues! raſcals! robbers! whoſe only ſign of fear is, you can't bear your own conſciences, ſo you are afraid of ſpirits; where's the echo, you conjur'd up juſt now?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Indeed! me lord, we heard an echo.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Did you? well, ſing again then, and let me hear it, I'll ſhew you a pattern of reſolution you rapſcallions.

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Now mark my lord, [ſings] "And we'll be wondrous merry."

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: [Behind in Robert's voice] "And we'll be wondrous merry."

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Alarm'd] Egad, but its an odd ſort of an echo.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: Suppoſe your honour was to ſpeak to it, perhaps it wou'd anſwer you civilly.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O! I dare ſay 'twill have a proper reſpect for my dignity,—what are you ghoſt or ſpirit?

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: [In Baron's voice.] "Ghoſt or ſpirit."

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: [Very much frighten'd] O lord! O lord!—why!—why! don't ſome of you ſpeak to me?—what—what,—are you afraid of?—Robert, what makes you look ſo pale?—for my part—I!—I!—I don't believe in apparitions, do you friend? [to Lewis.]

sp.speaker: Hugo
sp.p: [Behind] Lord William, my dear maſter Lord William!

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Hark my lord! there's a voice.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Oh! I am a loſt man,—but—why,—do you all tre-m-b-le ſo! [a bell tolls] O lord! there's the Curfew going at this hour.

div.stage: A Trumpet is heard at a diſtance, Lord William throws open the doors and walks with great ſolemnity in his father's armour, and exit. The trumpet is heard till he is quite off. The Baron &c. retire very much frighten'd.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O, dear me it is the old Baron's ghoſt! I have ſeen him wear that ſhield and helmet a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: [During this ſpeech of the Baron's, creeps round, as looking after Lord William.] O! my lord here's more miracles! the ſpirit has met ſome armed men and they are all fighting,—that's right,—that's right;—well done my boys—dammee they have kill'd the ghoſt, huzza.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Huzza,—huzza!—

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Egad, that's rare news, come lets go and ſee what its all about, I'll lead the way, do you follow me,—hey—no Robert, you ſhall go firſt;—no,—no,—ſtop, come back—we'll all go together, and then we can take care of one another— [drums and trumpets heard.]

div.stage: SCENE—An Apartment in the Caſtle, drums and trumpets without.
Enter Edward and Adela [Edward with a ſword and ſhield.]

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O Edward! I am frighten'd to death! it was an unlucky day for us when I turn'd fine lady and nothing but unlucky days have we had ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Lucky or unlucky,—I fancy there's an end of 'em now, bad as the days were, I wiſh they were to come over again.

div.stage: Enter Baron, [with his ſword drawn, and ſome old armour aukwardly put on.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O dear! O dear, they are all at it.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: What! what are they at?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Why, fighting, O my Lady Elinor! why don't you order your ſoldiers to fall on?—O how I hate a man that won't fight.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: What, is any body kill'd my lord!

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Kill'd, why we ſhall all be kill'd, men, women and children.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: For ſhame my lord! why do you ſtand idle here? your ſoldiers call on you to head 'em,—where's my brother?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Your brother, why what ſignifies your brother, why they are thirty thouſand ſtrong.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: I mean the Lord de Courcy.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: The Lord de Courcy,—why an't you—

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: O, no indeed my lord, I am not,—I am quite ſick of paſſing for a fine lady.

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.p: My lord, you muſt come immediately, they are forcing the caſtle gates.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Forcing the caſtle gates, O lord I ſhall die of a fright! and never live to be kill'd.

div.stage: SCENE—Changes to the Hall, after alarms of drums and trumpets.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: They have gain'd the Citadel, and we ſhall be put to the ſword.

div.stage: Enter De Courcy, Lord William and Knights.

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: Once more my noble friend, I congratulate you on your ſucceſs.

div.stage: Enter Lady Elinor, Cicely and Charles.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: De Cour
sp.p: My father contracted you in marriage with the young Baron of Oakland;—I preſent him to you, I deem'd him my enemy till I knew him, it is now my pride to call him my friend.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: This is a more valuable preſent my lord, than the life you gave me, when overpower'd by your ſoldiers in the garden you, ſtill thought me your enemy.

div.stage: Enter the Baron between two armed Men.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: O dear! ſpare my life, and I'll agree to any terms.

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: [To Lord William.] then Sir, begging your pardon for my boldneſs, I ſuppoſe you are the ghoſt we heard of?

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Yes, and you I ſuppoſe are the ſham Lady Elinor, we have heard of; egad, now I find how things are, I have reaſon to be in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: You Sir, [to Baron] have a right to an explanation, I ſcorn to owe my title to force; I am confirmed by my ſovereign in the dignity and eſtates of my father:—be aſſured however, that I ſhall be ambitious to prove myſelf your friend.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: And that's an ambition I ſhall be very glad to gratify you in.

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: [to Edward and Adela] As for this young couple, I hope I ſhall have the ſatisfaction of adding to their ſtore of Hymen's comforts.

sp.speaker: Ewd.
sp.p: I—Thank you my lord,—I begin to be much leſs inclined to Nobility after the buſtle I have ſeen to-night, and I'm fain to comforts myſelf with the old remark,—"that a title cannot beſtow happineſs."

sp.speaker: Adela
sp.p: Yes, but I can though there is a title for which I'd give up to all others, it is the wife of my Edward.

sp.speaker: L. Eli
sp.p: My fluttering heart cannot expreſs the joy it feels at your triumph. [to Lord William.]

sp.speaker: L. Wil
sp.p: A truimph crowned by the poſſeſſion of that heart which now approves it.

lg.l: The baniſh'd ills of heretofore
At happy diſtance viewing;
Of the paſt we'll think no more,
While future bliſs purſuing.
When engaged in Pleaſure's chace,
Never look behind you;
Back if you ſhou'd turn your face,
Misfortune's dust may blind you.
Here let the titled wedded pair,
A leſſon take from humble life;
Nor in the lady and the lord,
Forget the huſband and the wife.
Ne'er ſhall th' example us reprove,
Whoſe proudest boaſt ſhall be our love.

lg.head: SESTETTO.
lg.l: The preſent hour is ever ready,
To aſſume a ſmiling face;
If to wiſdom's councels steady,
Pleaſure's precepts you embrace.
Tho' no more I am a lord,
Give my love but this reward,
Rank and title I forego.
No, my Edward, ſay not ſo.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: The baniſh'd ills, &c.
